title: Brand playground
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(brand.yml)

brand <- read_brand_yml("../urban-institute.yml")

# library(showtext)
# font_add_google(brand$typography$fonts[[1]]$family)
# font_add_google(brand$typography$fonts[[2]]$family)
# showtext_auto()

brand_theme <- quarto::theme_brand_ggplot2("../urban-institute.yml") +
  theme(
    text = element_text(family = brand$typography$fonts[[1]]$family, size = 13)
  )

ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = drv)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "A plot") +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      brand$color$palette$blue,
      brand$color$palette$black,
      brand$color$palette$yellow
    )
  ) +
  brand_theme

title: Brand playground
text:
A second level heading
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

Heading 3
We use #1696d2◉ for Democrats and and #db2b27◉ for Republicans.

Inline code: #d7433b◉ or rgb(215, 67, 59)◉
Text: #38A6A5◉ or rgb(56,166,165)◉

title: Ada Lovelace
text: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace (née Byron; 10 December 1815 – 27 November 1852), also known as Ada Lovelace, was an English mathematician and writer chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage’s proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. She was the first to recognise that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation. Ada Lovelace is sometimes considered to be the first computer programmer.

title: Ada Lovelace
text: Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace (née Byron; 10 December 1815 – 27 November 1852), also known as Ada Lovelace, was an English mathematician and writer chiefly known for her work on Charles Babbage’s proposed mechanical general-purpose computer, the Analytical Engine. She was the first to recognise that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation. Ada Lovelace is sometimes considered to be the first computer programmer.

title: Ada Lovelace
text:
Accomplishments
Between 1842 and 1843, Lovelace translated an article by the military engineer Luigi Menabrea (later Prime Minister of Italy) about the Analytical Engine, supplementing it with seven long explanatory notes. These notes described a method of using the machine to calculate Bernoulli numbers which is often called the first published computer program.

title: Health and Wealth Around the World
text:
This analysis shows trends in life expectancy and GDP per capita for 142 countries from 1952 to 2007. The data was originally collected by Hans Rosling and the Gapminder foundation (Rosling et al. 2018).






ImportantKey findings



Health and wealth are correlated!
crumbs: Health and Wealth Around the World

title: Health and Wealth Around the World
text:
This analysis shows trends in life expectancy and GDP per capita for 142 countries from 1952 to 2007. The data was originally collected by Hans Rosling and the Gapminder foundation (Rosling et al. 2018).






ImportantKey findings



Health and wealth are correlated!
crumbs: Health and Wealth Around the World

title: Health and Wealth Around the World
text:
Continent-level trends
According to Figure 1, average life expectancy increased substantially between 1952 to 2007. Asia saw the biggest average increase (see Table 1).








Figure 1: Distribution of life expectancy within four continents









Table 1: Change in average life expectancy by continent





    

    

    
    
    
      
        
        

 
Averages
 

              
                Continent
                1952
                2007
                Change
              
        
        
        
                
                  Asia
                  46.3
                  70.7
                  24.4
                
                
                  Americas
                  53.3
                  73.6
                  20.3
                
                
                  Africa
                  39.1
                  54.8
                  15.7
                
                
                  Europe
                  64.4
                  77.6
                  13.2
                
                
                  Oceania
                  69.3
                  80.7
                  11.5
crumbs: Health and Wealth Around the World

title: Health and Wealth Around the World
text:
Country-level trends
Figure 2 recreates a part of Hans Rosling’s famous “200 countries, 200 years, 4 minutes” video and shows the relationship betweeen GDP per capita and life expectancy.








Figure 2: GDP per capita and life expectancy are closely related
crumbs: Health and Wealth Around the World
